description.narrative: The project will continue to enhance policy action for climate security in Central Asia through supporting more robust and coherent climate change action and increasing public awareness.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative: Initial results from Phase 1, including the PEA of climate action in Kyrgyzstan, and other evidence from target countries indicates that decision-makers, journalists and the public are not aware of or convinced that climate change is an urgent issue for the region, neither is there widespread awareness of the need for an urgent transition to renewable energy and a zero-carbon economy or of the social or economic opportunities that climate action and climate investment can bring - As of 2021 - No national scientific advisory platform to support the policy and decision making process - AS of 2021-Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan: there were not a part of any climate related discussion at any past COPs - As for 2021- Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan: no developed plans for MRV system establishment in place - As for 2021- No follow up action plan to implement the decision of COP26 - As of 2021- National statistics on gender disaggregated number of people involved in climate actions in countries (research, capacity building interventions, and awareness-raising campaigns) is not available - As of 2021- Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan: business sector are not represented in the climate change agenda and finance - As of 2021- Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan: 2500 young men and women, boys and girls actively participated in project actions

- By end of project in 2022 2 Regional report will be developed to inform the decision makers, as well as wide public are aware about the impacts, and opportunities of a climate resilient and low carbon economy in Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. These reports will then be used for driving a strong communications campaign which will act as a basis to transition the dialogue on climate change to one of the needs for urgent action - The targeted countries established the national advisory platforms on the working level - Three countries Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan: cooperated and contributed to formulation of a joint statement to implement the decisions of COP26 by end Q4 201 - Three countries Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan: Capacity building of national Governments increased and road map on establishment and operation of the MRV system to monitor and assess the implementation of mitigation activities, adaptation activities, and resources developed - Three countries Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan: Summary report outlining actions following COP26 and CMA3 decisions) prepared and communicated with Governments - Gender disaggregated statistics on number of people involved in climate actions (research, capacity building interventions, and awareness-raising campaigns) within the project activities is available - Three countries Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan: initiate a private sector advisory group on climate financing - Three countries Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan: 5000 young man and women, boys and girls actively participated in project actions

- Government participation in COP26 supported - A series of climate policy capacity building events (virtual/online and in-room) were conducted for more than 100 people (including. 45% women) from governmental and non-governmental representatives in preparation to COP-26 . The 1st National Debate Tournament on Climate Change was held among 40 young climate activists (including 50% women) to enhance youth participation for locally appropriate climate action . A Youth talk on Biodiversity “We’re Part of the Solution” was held among 16 local climate activists (including 30% women) discussing issues of biodiversity conservation in the face of climate change and proposed their solutions to improve the citys ecosystem . A cycling marathon “Bike for Nature” was organized jointly with Mayor’s office, civil society and private sector attracting over 400 people (professionals, amateurs, people with disabilities and youth) in climate action and demonstrating benefits of building climate resilient & green cities

1.1. At least 2 reports on climate impacts, opportunities & co-benefits of climate action in Tajikistan are produced by the regional team of Overseas Development Institute (ODI) with support of national experts. 2.1. Support provided for enhanced engagement with climate policymaking, monitoring and implementation of NDCs and the Paris Agreement at the national level. 2.2. Support rendered to the Government in preparation of the position paper for Tajikistan’s Climate Delegation team for COP27. 2.3. Engagement of national counterparts in UNFCCC and Paris Agreement post COP26 is enhanced through the events as follows: Regional Climate Policy Dialogue; Regional training on Art.6; National workshop on climate /green finance. 3.1. Youth regional cooperation on climate issues is enhanced through the engagement in following activities: Online Regional Youth event (with TJK youth participation), and National-level Climate Change Public Awareness event. 3.2. Awareness of schoolchildren, youth and academia about the need for climate action has been raised through the media campaign on climate change, contributing to the implementation of the State Programme on Environmental Education 2021-2025. 3.3. National-level private sector engagement is facilitated through the activities as follows: Public-private sector dialogue on climate action; Capacity building training for private sector; Regional Private Forum event.

1.1. Based on consultations with the main beneficiary, the Committee for Environmental Protection of Tajikistan (CoEP), the preparation of the 2 reports is being implemented in close partnership with the CoEP under relevant Letter of Agreement. To date the reports are drafted by ODI, and national consultations have been held on June 8, 2022, with the participation of the CoEP and the Agency for Hydrometeorology to review and deliver recommendations on data verification and finalizing the reports.
2.1. Draft proposal of the Climate Resilience and Green Development concept has been developed by UNDP CO, submitted and negotiated with FCDO. The thematic areas covered by the proposal address assessing economic cost of climate change, accelerating climate action through operationalization and implementation of NDC, formulation of Local Adaptation Plan, capacity building and knowledge management on climate resilient development and green growth, and racing towards net zero emission by 2060.
2.2. Terms of Reference developed to engage the consultancy to develop the Tajikistan’s Position Paper for COP27. The project sponsored 2 delegates from Tajikistan to participate in the 56th session of the UNFCCC Subsidiary Bodies, which will take place from 12 to 15 June 2022. The expected outputs from the participation in the meeting will be: (i) enhanced capacity in negotiation process; (ii) explored opportunities for partnership at the regional and international level and leverage climate change finance for Tajikistan; (iii) enhanced capacity on international climate change agreement and arrangements.
2.3. On 03-04 February 2022 representatives of Tajikistan’s governmental institutions contributed to the work of the Regional Climate Policy Dialogue on Participating in International Climate Negotiations and Implementing Nationally Climate Commitments , where the development and implementation of Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) were discussed. The meeting also allowed exchange experiences from participating at COP 26, discussing opportunities for improving the process of preparation/participation in Global Climate Negotiation and discussing countries readiness to implement the Paris Agreement. On 15 March 2022 Tajikistan’s participants joined the project regional webinar on Market mechanisms under the Paris Agreement (Article 6) and contributed to the discussions on joint approaches towards implementing the Paris Agreement, relevant CMA3 results and how to prepare for participation in market mechanisms.
3.1. On 15 April 2022 the educational “Climate Fresk” game was held between the teams of Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, aiming at raising awareness of students and enabling them to formulate more complete picture of the phenomenon of climate change by building cause-and-effect relationships. Following the success of this game (held in Tajikistan for the first time), on May 23rd the second “Climate Fresk” game was held at the national level with increased audience from national universities.
3.2. The national consultant and the NGO “Little Earth” have been engaged to conduct the “Youth Caravan” nation-wide event in 9 localities of Tajikistan until 30th June 2022.
3.3. On April 28th, 2022, the regional Private Sector and Climate Change Actions Forum was held. From Tajikistan’s side the presentations were delivered on supporting private sector climate actions through the financial mechanism of the UNFCCC, and on experience and lessons learned from partnering with the private sector.
